conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions Committee, I’m Student_D. School_D is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community and contribute academically and through school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately to maximize the chance of securing it. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I’m not highly prioritized, but applying first is still optimal; if rejected, I can move to my next choices in later rounds.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_D. Welcome to our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1. Student_D applied and ranks School_D first, so accepting would lock in a guaranteed match now. However, my true priority list ranks Student_A, Student_B, and Student_C above Student_D, and all schools share the same priority ordering. In a student-proposing process, Student_A will likely be accepted by School_B (their first choice) and not reach me; Student_B will likely be accepted by School_A (their first choice) and not reach me; Student_C will likely be accepted by School_C (their first choice) and not reach me. That makes the probability of receiving a higher-priority applicant later low. Student_E ranks School_D last and is unlikely to apply. Thus, accepting Student_D now maximizes expected outcome and avoids ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_B is my top choice, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat and would be honored to attend. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_B. Given all schools rank Student_A highest, an early [APPLY] to my first-choice should secure an [ACCEPT] before capacity fills.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your top choice. We’re delighted to offer you a seat at School_B and would be excited to welcome you to our community.
conversation.thought: Student_A is the top-ranked student on School_B's true priority list. They have applied in round 1 and explicitly state School_B is their top choice and they are ready to commit. With quota 1 and no higher-ranked alternative possible, accepting now secures the best feasible match and avoids any risk of losing them to another school in later rounds.

conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions Committee—I'm Student_E. School_E is my first-choice school, and I would be excited to commit if admitted. I’m applying now and would be grateful for your consideration. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Apply to my top choice (School_E) immediately. With identical school priorities (A > B > C > D > E), I have the lowest priority everywhere, so I should secure my best option before higher-priority students potentially take it later. A direct [APPLY] gives the only chance to lock in School_E now.

conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_E. After review, we are not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your effort and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_E last among all students. Although Student_E is applying now and would accept, I should consider whether higher-priority students (A–D) might apply later. Given Student_E ranks us first, they are likely to accept immediately, but accepting now could block a later match with a higher-priority student within my quota of 1. Since all schools share the same priority order and School_E is last choice for Students A–D, it is unlikely those higher-priority students will apply to School_E unless rejected elsewhere; however, they may eventually reach School_E after exhausting preferred options. With limited information in round 1 and to maximize chance of matching higher on my list, I will reject Student_E now and keep the seat open for potential higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_B. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m ready to commit if admitted. I’m strongly motivated by your academic environment and would be excited to contribute actively to classes and school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_A, and all schools share the same priority order with Student_A ranked above me. Since School_A has only 1 seat, I should apply immediately and make a clear, committed case so that if Student_A does not apply or chooses another school, I can secure the spot early. Delaying to talk risks losing the only seat to a higher-priority applicant.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_A is your first choice. We appreciate your enthusiasm for our academic environment and your willingness to commit.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. Congratulations—we look forward to having you join our community.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_B is applying and ranks School_A first, so accepting would secure a committed match immediately. However, School_A’s true top priority is Student_A, who ranks School_A second (after School_B) and may apply later; rejecting Student_B now could allow pursuit of Student_A but risks ending unmatched if Student_A commits elsewhere. With only one message in round 1 and no indication Student_A is approaching, the safest way to maximize a high-ranked match within quota is to accept Student_B (ranked 2nd on our true list) rather than gamble for Student_A.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions, I’m Student_C. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your community. I’m applying formally and would be grateful to be considered for your available seat.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C, and there is no prior interaction yet. Since each school has capacity 1 and all schools share the same priority order (Student_A > Student_B > Student_C ...), I should apply immediately to my first choice to maximize the chance of securing it before seats fill through other students' applications.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission and would be happy to welcome you to our community.
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority ranks Student_A > Student_B > Student_C > Student_D > Student_E. I have quota 1 and currently only Student_C has applied to me this round. While I might prefer A or B, neither has contacted me yet, and Student_C ranks School_C as their first choice, making acceptance likely to lock in a stable match. Given no competing applicants in my inbox and the risk of ending unmatched if I wait, I will accept Student_C now.

conversation.message: Dear School_E Admissions Committee, thank you again for considering my earlier application. School_E remains my clear first choice, and I would commit immediately if given the opportunity. Could you please let me know whether there is any possibility of reconsideration (e.g., if a seat opens later) and what additional information, if any, would be helpful for you to review from me? [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_E is my top true preference and it is the only unmatched school remaining. Although I was rejected previously (likely because higher-priority students applied), I should continue engaging to see if circumstances have changed or if there is any possibility of reconsideration or waitlist-style flexibility. Since a second [APPLY] is unlikely to succeed without new information, I will [TALK] to express continued strong interest and ask if there is any path to be reconsidered if a spot opens.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E. At this moment, we are not able to change our earlier decision, but it is possible for us to reconsider later if our seat remains available after additional rounds.

If you would like to be considered in that scenario, please feel free to check back with us in a later round and, if appropriate, submit a new [APPLY] at that time. In the meantime, we encourage you to continue conversations with other schools so you have the strongest set of options.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is the lowest-ranked student on School_E’s true priority list. We still have 1 seat, but higher-priority students (A–D) all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to approach us early; however, it is still strategically better to keep the seat open for now rather than commit to our lowest priority immediately. Student_E is currently only TALKing (not applying), so we should respond with TALK, indicate we can reconsider later if the seat remains, and encourage them to continue exploring other options while staying in contact.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your earlier feedback. I’m reaching out again because School_E remains my clear first choice, and if offered admission I will accept immediately.

Given that your seat is still available this round, I would be grateful to be reconsidered and am submitting a renewed application.

Sincerely,
Student_E  
[APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. School_E indicated it may reconsider in later rounds if the seat remains available, so the best move is to re-apply now with a clear commitment to accept immediately if admitted, while keeping the message concise and respectful.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your renewed application and for your continued interest in School_E.

After review, we are not able to offer you admission this round. We are keeping our seat available as we continue through the matching process. As mentioned previously, if our seat remains open in a later round, we may be able to reconsider at that time.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is the lowest on School_E’s true priority list (A > B > C > D > E). Although Student_E is willing to commit immediately and our seat is currently open, accepting now would forfeit the chance to match with any higher-priority student who may reach School_E in later rounds (e.g., if they are rejected by their top choices). Given we are only at round 3 (early) and have no match yet, it is strategically better to keep the seat available and continue to signal possible reconsideration later rather than lock in the lowest-ranked option now.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for keeping the door open to possible reconsideration in later rounds. I’m writing again because School_E remains my unequivocal first choice, and if admitted I will accept immediately.

If there is any additional information that would help you make a decision (updated grades, recommendations, short statement of fit), I can provide it right away. Otherwise, I respectfully ask to be reconsidered for your open seat this round.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Although I have been rejected twice, School_E indicated it may reconsider in later rounds if the seat remains open. I will submit another concise, commitment-focused application, emphasizing immediate acceptance and willingness to provide any additional materials, to maximize the chance of reconsideration now that the seat is still available.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for offering to provide additional materials.

After review, we are not able to offer you admission this round, as we are still holding our seat while we proceed through additional rounds of the matching process.

If our seat remains unfilled in later rounds, you are welcome to check back and submit another [APPLY] at that time.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is last on our true priority list. Our seat is still open, and higher-priority students (A–D) all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to apply until very late (if at all). However, accepting Student_E now would lock in our only seat and eliminate any chance—however small—of matching with a higher-priority student later. Given our objective to match as high as possible on our priority list and that we can continue to hold the seat, we should reject again and keep the option value of waiting.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your continued time and for explaining that reconsideration may be possible in later rounds if the seat remains open. Since we are now in Round 5 and your seat is still available, could you please share what specific condition would make you comfortable extending an offer (e.g., waiting to see whether higher-priority students apply, a particular round threshold, or any additional information you would like from me)?

School_E remains my first choice, and if offered admission at any point I will accept immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Given repeated rejections while they hold the seat, a softer [TALK] is more strategic this round to learn what condition would trigger reconsideration and to signal immediate commitment without forcing another likely rejection.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for your thoughtful question.

The main condition for us to extend an offer is simply whether any higher-priority students (relative to our published priority order) reach out to us and apply while our seat is still open. At this stage, additional materials (grades, recommendations, statements) would not change your position in our priority order, so they would not be decisive.

Practically, our plan is to keep the seat open for a few more rounds to see whether any higher-priority applicants enter the market for School_E due to outcomes elsewhere. If our seat remains unclaimed by then, we will be more comfortable making an offer to a lower-priority applicant.

If you would like, please check back and submit a new [APPLY] in Round 8; if we are still unfilled at that point, we will re-evaluate immediately.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is last on our true priority list. Our quota is 1 and still open. Given full information, higher-priority students (A-D) all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to apply unless rejected everywhere else. However, holding the seat longer preserves the (small) chance to match with a higher-priority student if cascading rejections occur. Since Student_E sent [TALK] (not an [APPLY]) and has repeatedly applied, we can continue to delay while being transparent about the condition: we are waiting to see if any higher-priority students approach us; no extra materials will change priority. We can suggest a specific later round to re-apply, keeping flexibility.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your guidance last round. I remain fully committed to School_E as my first choice and would accept immediately if offered.

I understand your plan is to hold the seat a few more rounds to see whether any higher-priority students apply, and that you suggested I submit a new [APPLY] in Round 8 if you are still unfilled. Could you please confirm that Round 8 is still the right time for me to re-apply, and whether any earlier condition (e.g., if no higher-priority applicants have reached out by the end of Round 7) would make it appropriate for me to submit an earlier [APPLY]?

Sincerely,
Student_E

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. However, School_E has explicitly asked me to check back and submit a new APPLY in Round 8 after they wait a few more rounds for higher-priority students. Applying again in Round 6 is likely to yield another rejection and could reduce goodwill. Therefore, I will send a TALK message now to reaffirm my commitment, confirm they still want me to wait until Round 8, and ask whether any earlier trigger (e.g., if no higher-priority applicants have contacted them by Round 7) would lead them to consider me sooner.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in—and yes, Round 8 is still the right time for you to submit a new [APPLY] if we remain unfilled.

If you would like a clear earlier condition: if no higher-priority students (Student_A–Student_D) have submitted an [APPLY] to School_E by the end of Round 7, then submitting your [APPLY] at the start of Round 8 is the earliest point at which we plan to re-evaluate and potentially move forward.

Between now and then, an earlier [APPLY] from you would not change our decision (we are intentionally keeping the seat available through Round 7 to preserve flexibility in case a higher-priority applicant enters).

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list ranks Student_E last. Student_E is highly committed and keeps applying/talking, but accepting now could block a chance (however small) to match with a higher-priority student (A–D) if they become unmatched and decide to apply to School_E later. Given the market preferences, A–D all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to apply unless they strike out elsewhere; still, with many rounds remaining, holding the seat preserves the option value. Student_E sent [TALK], so I should respond with [TALK] and reiterate the planned re-apply timing and conditions without committing early.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your clear guidance. I understand that an [APPLY] from me in Round 7 would not change your decision because you are intentionally holding the seat through the end of this round to see whether any higher-priority students apply.

Could you please confirm whether any of Student_A–Student_D have submitted an [APPLY] to School_E as of now in Round 7? If not, I will submit my formal [APPLY] immediately at the start of Round 8 as you instructed.

School_E remains my first choice, and if offered admission at any point, I will accept immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. School_E explicitly said an APPLY before Round 8 will not change their decision; they plan to hold the seat through Round 7 unless a higher-priority student applies. Therefore, the best move in Round 7 is to send a TALK message to maintain engagement, confirm no higher-priority APPLYs have arrived, and signal I will submit an APPLY at the start of Round 8 exactly as requested.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in.

As of now in Round 7, we have not received an [APPLY] to School_E from any of Student_A–Student_D.

Our plan remains the same: we will hold the seat through the end of Round 7 to preserve flexibility in case a higher-priority applicant enters. If that does not happen, please submit your formal [APPLY] at the start of Round 8, and we will re-evaluate immediately at that time.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is lowest on our true priority list, while Student_A–Student_D are higher. No other students contacted us this round, and Student_E is only talking (not applying). Given our stated plan to hold the seat through end of Round 7 to preserve flexibility in case a higher-priority student applies, we should not change course now. We can confirm that no higher-priority applications have been received so far in Round 7 and reiterate that Round 8 is the earliest point we will reconsider Student_E, at which time we would be prepared to accept if still unfilled and no higher-priority applicant has applied.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

Thank you for your guidance and for confirming that no higher-priority students (Student_A–Student_D) had applied as of the end of Round 7. As you instructed, I am submitting my formal application at the start of Round 8.

School_E remains my clear first choice, and if offered admission I will accept immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. School_E explicitly instructed me to submit a formal APPLY at the start of Round 8 if no higher-priority students applied by end of Round 7, which they confirmed. Submitting APPLY now maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before any new higher-priority applicant appears.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for re-applying at the start of Round 8 as discussed, and for your continued, clear commitment to School_E.

We have reviewed your application this round and are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. We appreciate your patience throughout the process and look forward to welcoming you.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Our true priority is A>B>C>D>E. No higher-priority students (A–D) have applied through Round 7, and Student_E followed our instruction to re-apply in Round 8 with a credible commitment to accept immediately. Given the long wait already and the risk of ending unmatched if we continue holding out, accepting Student_E now secures a match. Since our priorities are identical across schools and Student_E ranks us first, this is stable for us and prevents losing them to another school later.
